posts.cooked:
A. I recently learned that delivery indicators are in some cases send by Signals servers. For example when sealed sender is not working or is sabotaged, or on the first message where sealed sender is not being used. In these cases delivery indicators can be manipulated by Signals servers, which makes them vulnerable to state actors.

B. Furthermore I learned that in the case sealed sender is working, delivery indicators are send by the client of the receiver (which is great), however this also means that if the receiver blocks you, you won’t be receiving any delivery indicators anymore.

C. Delivery indicators reveal the moment you have internet access, and that could reveal something about your everyday life.

I think it would good to consider removing delivery indicators altogether for the following reasons:

Reason 1, state actors could send fake delivery indicators:
Say the Signal server was taken over by an evil organization. They could still not read messages, but could they send fake delivery indicators, while actually not delivering the messages at all. This could done by a state actor to cause the illusion that someone was still in control over his phone after he had already been taken into interrogation or custody. Signal strives for users to know what information is with whom. One way to compromise that security is by giving user the illusion that their contact is aware of recent information, while in fact he never actually received it.

Reason 2, delivery indicators could hint you that you got blocked
It’s a great thing that Signal doesn’t show others if you have blocked them or not. Unfortunately if you are using sealed sender, as soon as you block someone you stop sending back delivery indicators, which can give a hint to others that you have blocked them. Furthermore as soon as you unblock them, delivery indicators are being send back again for every new message. Delivery indicators are leaking information about whether you blocked someone or not.

Reason 3, delivery indicators reveal the moment you have internet access
Many people don’t have and internet connection on their mobile device 24/7, and thus knowing when they do have internet reveals when they get home, or at their work, or some other place where their device connects to a wifi network. Signal reveals when that moment is taking place because at that very moment it sends out delivery indicators. this is a minor, yet a real, leak of privacy sensitive metadata.

Note that delivery indicators are not an essential part of a messenger app. We can message without them, and we still have the optional read receipts in case we want to let others know whether we received and have seen their messages. On a technical level the client of the sender needs to know if a message was successfully handed off to the server but it does not need to know if the message was successfully delivered to the client of the receiver.

This feature request was inspired by two discussions: Are Signal delivery indicators and read receipts also end-to-end encrypted? - #23 by Meteor0id , Not great for Privacy: blocked contacts can still see the exact times at which you are connected to the internet (eg. when you get home or arrive at work) - #43 by newuser and Delivery Receipts / Call Ringing Privacy

posts.cooked:
Dave_Niezby:

Let’s face it, this app is mostly used by friends and family communicating without big tech eyes and their advertisers, etc.

The above quote i.m.o. this sums up your reply well. Of course for most users these details are irrelevant. Yet for some people they could be, and it would be good if Signal aimed to also facilitate those users.

Dave_Niezby:

Evil organizations? WTF chats are you participating in? This is not James Bond’s chat service.

Think about a protester in HongKong who is communicating with a fellow protest leader, but fears the Chinese government intercepts their chats or leads him into a trap to arrest him for taking part in protests. This threat is not just fictional, it can be real to some people.

Dave_Niezby:

Um…So? If you blocked someone what do you care if they know you blocked them or not?

Blocking others should stay without fear of consequences which can be prevented. It’s much easier to block someone if you can rely that Signal will never give the other person evidence that they got blocked by you. You may not have experienced a case where this matters, but to some people it matters a lot if their contacts can see the difference between being blocked and not being blocked. Signal has been designed with this in mind as evident from the support article on blocking, and it would make sense to try and uphold that design decision.

Dave_Niezby:

if you’re on Mobile, when do you NOT have internet access

Whenever I am not in wifi range. Many people do not pay for mobile data, or turn it off when they are not using it. Wifi often auto-connects. Information about when someone comes online can be very useful to law-enforcement (also in oppressive regimes), also to stalkers etc.

Yes, delivery indicators will be of no concern to most users. But That doesn’t mean they are a non-issue. There are use cases where delivery indicators unnecessarily leak metadata to conversation partners. Delivery information doesn’t need to be available to anyone, and so it would be best not to make it available.

Meteor0id:

this also means that if the receiver blocks you, you won’t be receiving any delivery indicators anymore.

Is that true? Wouldn’t it just revert back to the server sending them?

Meteor0id:

Note that delivery indicators are not an essential part of a messenger app. We can message without them, and we still have the optional read receipts in case we want to let others know whether we received and have seen their messages.

I think being able to see whether your message has reached the recipient’s device is very useful for determining whether you need to attempt another mode of communication. If messages aren’t making it to them, they can’t read them and will not be aware that you are even trying to reach them. Being aware of that can be important, so I’d say it’s close to essential.

They can also be useful for troubleshooting issues with messages.

I think it is enough to make it optional like read receipts.

wrt your reason 1, it is enough that clients only use receipts sent by clients. Server can’t fake this.

wrt your reason 2, I pointed out in the post that you’ve linked that with optional receipts it is enough for the client to not send receipts to blocked/unaccepted people. Then it isn’t straightforward to see whether you’re blocked or delivery receipts have been turned off. However blocking can always be detected by carefully monitoring debug logs for failure of profile fetching.

wrt your reason 3, receipts being optional should be enough. However it should really be a per chat option since I would want to send read and delivery receipts to some people and not others.

Delivery receipts are useful because people aren’t always online and even if they have mobile data turned on, there are issues with battery optimizations, app being killed, etc. You at least want to be sure that the message was delivered.

Herohtar:

Is that true? Wouldn’t it just revert back to the server sending them?

Not if sealed sender allow from anyone is turned on. You can see the confirmation in the beta thread that is linked in one of the linked threads.

If messages aren’t making it to them, they can’t read them and will not be aware that you are even trying to reach them. Being aware of that can be important, so I’d say it’s close to essential.

They can also be useful for troubleshooting issues with messages.

Fair point but does it weight up against knowing more than necessary? Think about sending someone a letter (on paper). The mailman doesn’t come back to your door to confirm the letter was delivered successfully, nor does the receiver let you know he received it. He replies or he does not. You can reasonably assume the letter was delivered because the system is reliable.
Note that the server can still confirm that it received your message and will do it’s best to hand it off to the receiver, I just ask to remove that final confirmation from the receiver that he retrieved the message from the server. The server will still know that the message was handed off successfully, and if something technically is going wrong the server can know about it.

Meteor0id:

Think about a protester in HongKong who is communicating with a fellow protest leader, but fears the Chinese government intercepts their chats or leads him into a trap to arrest him for taking part in protests. This threat is not just fictional, it can be real to some people.

It’s not fictional and not outside the abilities of the Chinese Government. HOWEVER…The idea is far fetched. IF one were a protestor in China do you think you should be using ANY form of electronic communication? Especially from an app that in order to be downloaded IN China is required to make the code available - probably so they could track people trying to hide from them?

An app developer cannot go around developing changes and features for .01% of it’s potential user base (the % is a little hyperboli) I also highly doubt that China would allow the app in the first place.

So 99.9% of the world won’t have to worry about that point. So why waste time and resources for development on it. It makes no logical sense.

In reference to receipts:
I DO agree that read receipts and delivery notifications would be great if they were optional.

Meteor0id:

C. Delivery indicators reveal the moment you have internet access, and that could reveal something about your everyday life.

You lost me at ‘C’.

I am a huge critic of anything that breaches privacy free will. But this? I mean, it could reveal that you have a phone. Yes. Who doesn’t have a phone?

For me, anyone who messages me will always get a delivery message. At any time of the day or night. I don’t know of anyone who turns their phone off.

What could it reveal? I don’t get the point, unfortunately.

If you expect everyone to be online all the time, then delivery indicators are even more worthless. I’ve rarely seen a message not being delivered by Signal. The service is fairly reliable. Even the recent outage seems to have been a bug in a beta release. The uptime is commendable given that they’re running on donations and have a small team.

The only issue is when a contact rarely uses Signal and the OS kills the app and the contact never realizes that there are pending messages. I have a couple contacts like this.

Many of my contacts, including me, aren’t online all the time. Delivery receipts indicate to me when they’re online. The thing with unnecessary leakage of info is that individually/separately they might not amount to much but the more such datapoints you have, the more you could learn. Have a look at the contact joining notification thread for examples (another thing which many people seem to think isn’t an issue).

newuser:

I genuinely do not know of anyone who uses delivery receipts as an indication of being ‘Online’ as I do not know anyone who turns their phones off unless it’s out of battery.

posts.cooked:
anon94207282:

I am a huge critic of anything that breaches privacy free will. But this? I mean, it could reveal that you have a phone. Yes. Who doesn’t have a phone?

I have experienced stalking. Knowing when someone comes online is a big deal, and being able to hide that from others is very important.

Meteor0id:

Knowing when someone comes online is a big deal, and being able to hide that from others is very important.

Completely agree. Stalking / harassment is a huge issue. Unless I’m missing something, just turn off notifications if you don’t want to be disturbed?

I may be missing something if there is a different way of notifying on Android as I don’t understand that OS.

iOS exposes the timestamps of the receipts. Android does it only in group chats. It could be used to stalk if one were inclined to do so.

Personally, I think there should always be an option to limit leakage of info. The work to introduce a global toggle takes 5 mins (just duplicate what is done for read receipts and turn off server receipts). Making it something you can control in each chat is a bit more work.

newuser:

It could be used to stalk if one were inclined to do so.

I have iOS. I’m not sure how anyone could use it to ‘stalk’ me? Likewise, I’m not sure how I could stalk someone else? It is a time stamp of a delivery receipt?
Unless, of course, the recipient creates a pattern of behaviour for themselves by only allowing messages to be delivered at certain times.

I can understand this point to a degree. Sometimes I turn my notifications off and, until I open the app, there is only 1 tick showing for the recipient. There is a use case for this.

I have seen similar features in WhatsApp++ - where you can essentially close everything down. But then you have people calling about 2 hours later saying “are you off WhatsApp now as it’s not been delivered”.

I’m all for it if people want to use it and is as easy as you say it is. It’s not something I’d ever use, personally, but it does provide something over other apps - so a +1.

Meteor0id:

If someone notices you suddenly don’t give off delivery indicators anymore he knows you either blocked him or turned off delivery indicators specifically for your chat with him. Either way he takes it personally. Better just remove delivery indicators entirely.

Or you changed your number.
I think removing delivery indicators would be a major blow to usability and usefulness of the app. The benefits far outweigh the edge cases, which can and should be handled in different ways.
The single best thing you can do if you have someone stalking you that you really want to disconnect from is to change your number. Quite drastic, a bit inconvenient, but appropriate and necessary.
The vast majority of people who have issues with other people block them, and the vast majority of blocked people will just move on.

If you look at message details you can see the exact time the message was delivered/read. The delivery time isn’t useful if the person is always online. If not, as pointed out, it reveals when you’re online. Just that info might not reveal much but again it can provide data which combined with other things can make it easier to stalk.

DonDino:

I think removing delivery indicators would be a major blow to usability and usefulness of the app.

Delivery receipts are definitely useful but if I turned it off for someone then it’s because I don’t care how inconvenient it is for them to chat with me. Random people who message me and people I’ve blocked fall into this category for sure.

DonDino:

The single best thing you can do if you have someone stalking you that you really want to disconnect from is to change your number. Quite drastic, a bit inconvenient, but appropriate and necessary.

Agreed, to a degree. However, prevention is better than cure and many people don’t realise they’re being stalked or to the extent. For this reason, I’m very pro-privacy to the fullest extent. The ‘Online’ status thread that you created back in 2018 provoked a very reasoned debate and I wholeheartedly think that ‘feature’ would be overwhelmingly misused as it is on WhatsApp.

This issue of delivery receipts follows on with similar scenarios. But maybe less so, or depends on how the user controls their Signal app. If they only have their phone on between 1300-1400, then this does reveal information about them. If they keep their phone on 24/7, then it doesn’t reveal much if anything.

On this basis, it’s not a bad feature request suggestion. I just wonder how much it would be used.
